thread.title: Bernard Tomic to reach career-high ranking of 18
thread.title_full: Bernard Tomic to reach career-high ranking of 18

author: LEO SCHLINK
title: Bernard Tomic to reach career-high ranking of 18
text:
Video Image Novak Djokovic too good for Bernard Tomic 0:51 Tennis: Novak Djokovic proved to be too good for Bernard Tomic, defeating the Aussie 7-6, 6-1 in their quarter-final match at the Shanghai Rolex Masters.
October 17th 2015 4 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/Tennis/ Bernard Tomic reaches for a return against Novak Djokovic in the Shanghai Masters.
LEO SCHLINK Herald Sun BERNARD Tomic will claim a career-high mark of world No. 18 when the rankings are updated on Monday.
Tomic’s effort to reach the Shanghai Rolex Masters quarter-finals will push the Queenslander up two spots and within reach of the season-ending top 15 ranking he is chasing.
Tomic, 22, lost 7-6 (8-6) 6-1 in China to world No. 1 Novak Djokovic, convinced he is continuing to make significant inroads.
“I think this has to be one of the best sets I’ve played, probably,’’ Tomic said.
“It was quality tennis from both ends and it came down to one point in the tie-break where I had a chance at five-all, six-all as well and unfortunately I didn’t get it.
“He’s the best player in the world ... it was very, very good tennis.
“I brought this tournament’s confidence into this match in the first set and looking back last week he didn’t lose more than a 6-3 (set) against quality, quality players. So for me it was very, very important this first set and after I think I was dead.
“I was trying to stay with him, but he looked so fresh and so energetic, and every point I kept playing I was digging myself in a deeper hole in the second set.’’
Tomic has three tournaments left this season — Valencia, Stockhom and Paris.
If the baselines is able to climb two more spots, he will enjoy protection from the high seeds at the Australian Open until the fourth round.
Tomic started the season ranked 71st — and languished at No. 124 little more than a year ago — as he rebuilt form and fitness from double hip surgery.
He last month joined a select group of contemporary Australian men to feature in the top 20.
Grand slam champions John Newcombe, Lleyton Hewitt and Pat Rafter all reached No. 1 under the ATP Tour Emirates computer system, while Wimbledon winner Pat Cash peaked at No.4.
US Open finalist Mark Philippoussis (No. 8) and grand slam singles semi-finalists Wally Masur (No. 15), Jason Stoltenberg (No. 19), Mark Woodforde (No. 19) and Todd Woodbridge (No. 19) are among modern Australian players to crack the elite.
 Tomic to reach career-high rank
